contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=April 2009}} {{Japanese city |Name=Higashimatsuyama |JapaneseName=東松山 |Prefecture=[[Saitama Prefecture|Saitama]] |Region=[[Kantō region|Kantō]] |MapImage=Higashimatsuyama in Saitama Prefecture Ja.svg |Area_km2=65.33 |Population=89,647 |PopDate=April 1, 2011 |Density_km2=1372.22 |Coords= |LatitudeDegrees= 36 |LatitudeMinutes= 3 |LatitudeSeconds= |LongtitudeDegrees= 139 |LongtitudeMinutes= 24 |LongtitudeSeconds= |Postal code= |Area code= |Mayor =Koichi Morita (since August 2010) |Tree = [[Pinus]] |Flower = [[Paeonia suffruticosa]] |Bird = |SymbolImage= Flag of Higashimatsuyama, Saitama.svg{{!}}border |SymbolDescription= Flag |CityHallPostalCode = |CityHallAddress= |CityHallPhone= |CityHallLink = {{URL|http://www.city.higashimatsuyama.lg.jp}} |Elevation= }} {{Nihongo|'''Higashimatsuyama'''|東松山市|Higashimatsuyama-shi|literally "East Pine-Tree Mountain"}} is a city in [[Saitama Prefecture]], Japan. As of April 1, 2011, the city has an estimated population of 89,647 (35,720 households) and a population density of 1,372.22 persons per km². The total area is 65.33 km². The city was founded on July 1, 1954. The city is served by [[Takasaka Station|Takasaka]] and [[Higashi-Matsuyama Station|Higashi-Matsuyama]] Stations on the [[Tōbu Tōjō Line]], providing a direct rail service to [[Ikebukuro]] in Tokyo. In 1967, the Maruki Gallery for the [[Hiroshima Panels]], was established in Higashi-Matsuyama. ==Sister cities== Higashimatsuyama has been [[town twinning|twinned]] with the city of [[Nijmegen]] in the Netherlands since 1996.<ref>[http://www.city.higashimatsuyama.lg.jp/out/english/english.htm Information of Higashimatsuyama City] Retrieved 7 November 2012.</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Official website|http://www.city.higashimatsuyama.lg.jp}} {{ja icon}} {{Saitama}} [[Category:Cities in Saitama Prefecture]]
